questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mean > Median > Mode 

 

  • The provided box-whisker plot illustrates a distribution that is positively skewed (right skewed).
  • In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.
  • To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Right skew curve: Mean > Median > Mode
  • In Left skew curve: Mean < Median < Mode
  • In Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode.

choices.text: IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy.
100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient.
Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate.
IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months.

questions.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to reduce anemia through six targeted interventions. Correct regarding administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IFA is started from the second trimester of pregnancy onwards, continues during lactation till 6 months

 

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program is a government initiative in India aimed at reducing the prevalence of anemia across various age groups. The strategy follows a "6x6x6" approach – 6 target beneficiaries, 6 Interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.
  • 6 Target beneficiaries - 6 to 59 months old Children; 5 to 9 year old children; 10-19 years old adolescents, reproductive-age women (20-49 year), pregnant women, and lactating mothers.
  • For pregnant women, Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation is a key intervention. IFA is administered starting from the second trimester of pregnancy and is continued throughout the remainder of the pregnancy (180 days). This supplementation is then repeated during the first six months of lactation, also for 180 days. The supplementation is given regardless of the hemoglobin status of the woman, making it a primary preventive measure against anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFA supplementation is administered only during pregnancy: This statement is incorrect because IFA supplementation continues during the first six months of lactation after the pregnancy period, not just during pregnancy.

 

Option B. 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient: This is incorrect as the recommended course for IFA supplementation in both pregnancy and lactation is 180 days, not 100 days.

 

Option C. Supplementing IFA during the First trimester is adequate: This option is incorrect because IFA supplementation typically begins in the second trimester of pregnancy, not the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program should begin in the second trimester of pregnancy and continue through the first six months of lactation, with a recommended course of 180 days each during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the association between the consumption of vegetarian/non-vegetarian food with certain diseases. The incidence of disease was evaluated in those two groups. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used when evaluating the association between categorical variables, such as the consumption of vegetarian or non-vegetarian food and the incidence of certain diseases. This study involves comparing the occurrence of diseases in two groups (vegetarians vs. non-vegetarians), which represents qualitative data.

 

The Chi-square test is specifically designed for non-parametric data (data that does not follow a normal distribution) and is ideal for comparing proportions, percentages, or counts between two or more groups. In this context, the test helps determine whether there is a significant association between diet type and disease occurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Paired student’s t-test: The paired student’s t-test is used for comparing means within the same group at two different times (before and after an intervention). It is suitable for continuous data, not for comparing categorical data between two distinct groups.

 

Option B. Unpaired student’s t-test: The unpaired student’s t-test compares the means of two independent groups, such as test scores or measurements. This test is used for continuous, normally distributed data and is not suitable for categorical or qualitative data like the incidence of diseases.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric test used for comparing two paired groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is similar to the paired t-test but for ordinal or continuous data, making it unsuitable for categorical data such as disease incidence.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chi-square test is used to determine the association between categorical variables, especially when comparing the incidence of outcomes across two or more independent groups.

questions.text: Dr. Verma is examining the criteria used to establish the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) for nutrients and focuses on the typical characteristics of a "reference woman". Which of the following correctly describes this reference woman used for RDA calculations? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Weight 55 kgs

 

  • Weight of 55 kgs: This is used as a standard measurement in RDA calculations to reflect an average baseline for determining nutrient needs in adult women.
  • It represents a balance that is thought to be typical or ideal for maintaining health without excessive caloric intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference woman used in the calculation of recommended daily allowance (RDA)

 

  • Aged between 19-39 years
  • Non pregnant, non-lactating
  • Weight=55kgs
  • Height = 1.61 m
  • BMI=21.2
  • Free from disease and physically fit for active work
  • Engaged in moderate activity for 8 hours on each working day
  • Spends 8 hours in bed, 4-6 hours in sitting and moving, 2hours in walking and in active recreation or household activities.

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures of anthropometry? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight-for-height

 

Wasting in a child is an indicator of acute malnutrition and is assessed using the weight-for-height measure. This metric evaluates whether a child’s weight is appropriate for their height, which reflects their current nutritional status. Wasting indicates that a child has lost weight rapidly in relation to their height, usually due to insufficient nutrient intake or disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight-for-age: This measure is used to assess whether a child is underweight, which is an acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option C. Height-for-age: This measure is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. Stunting reflects a long-term deficiency in nutrition, resulting in reduced growth in height.

 

Option D. Height-for-weight: This option is not a standard anthropometric measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wasting in a child is assessed using the weight-for-height measure, indicating acute malnutrition

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

choices.text: Both mean as well as the median will increase
Mean will increase but median will remain same

questions.text: In a class of 25 students, the student with the highest weight (= 39 kg) was wrongly recorded as 93 kg. What will happen to central tendency now? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean will increase but median will remain same

 

In this scenario, the mean will increase because the sum of all weights will increase due to the incorrect recording of 39 kg as 93 kg. This error adds an additional 54 kg to the total sum of weights, thus increasing the mean when this new sum is divided by the total number of students (25).

 

The median, however, remains unaffected because it is the middle value in an ordered list of numbers. Changing the highest value does not impact the middle value in the sorted list.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Mean will decrease: This is incorrect because the mean will increase due to the additional weight recorded.

 

Option B. Median will increase: This is incorrect because the median is the middle value and is not affected by changes in the highest or lowest values unless those changes impact the middle value directly.

 

Option C. Both mean as well as the median will increase: This is incorrect as only the mean increases while the median remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Errors in extreme values (highest or lowest) affect the mean but do not affect the median. In this case, the mean increases while the median remains unchanged.

 

Note - Measures of Central Tendency –

 

1. Mean (Average): Is obtained as sum of all values divided by the no. of values.

Mean = S x/n

2. Median: Middle-most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

Median = ((n + 1)/2)th value in ascending order

3. Mode: Most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, recently married, visits a local healthcare facility with her husband for family planning counseling. The healthcare provider advises various contraceptive options and takes some details to add to a specific register. This register helps the healthcare workers monitor and provide reproductive health services to eligible couples in the region. At which level of the healthcare system is this "Eligible Couple Register" typically maintained? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subcenter

 

A couple where the female belongs to the reproductive age group of 15-49 years is considered to be an eligible couple.

 

Eligible couple register is maintained at subcenter by health worker female/ ANM.

 

‘Eligible Couple Register’ is a basic document for organizing family planning work. It is regularly updated by ANM/ HW female with the help of ASHA, for the area falling within her jurisdiction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eligible Couple Register is maintained at subcentre, primarily by female health worker/ ANM

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of School Health under Ayushman Bharat Program? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Monthly IFA supplementations

 

The Ayushman Bharat Program includes a comprehensive school health component aimed at improving the health and hygiene of school children. The key components include:

 

  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS): This involves the distribution of iron and folic acid supplements on a weekly basis to prevent anemia among school children. Monthly supplementation is not part of this program; hence, "Monthly IFA supplementations" is the incorrect option.
  • Sanitary Napkins Distribution: Under the menstrual hygiene scheme, sanitary napkins branded as "Freedays" are distributed to adolescent girls to promote menstrual hygiene.
  • Albendazole for Deworming: Deworming through albendazole is conducted to reduce the prevalence of intestinal worm infestations among school-aged children.
  • Health Check-ups: Regular health screenings are conducted to assess the physical and mental fitness of students, ensuring early identification and management of health issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat School Health Program includes weekly IFA supplementation, not monthly, along with other health initiatives like menstrual hygiene, deworming, screening health check-ups, physical & mental fitness, Research and Vaccination

questions.text: Which biological method will you use to control mosquito larvae? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gambusia fish

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fishes, such as Gambusia, Poecilia, and Labister. These fish species feed on mosquito larvae, helping to control their population.

 

Note - Antilarval chemical method – Paris green (stomach poison)

 

Methods like spraying (insecticides – DDT, pyrethrum, malathion) and distributing nets are measures to control adult mosquitoes but not the larvae stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDT Spray 3 times a month - This option is incorrect because spraying is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Option B. Distribute nets - This option is incorrect because mosquito nets are a physical barrier used to prevent adult mosquitoes from biting, but they do not control the larvae stage.

 

Option D. Pyrethrum spray - This option is incorrect because pyrethrum spray is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fish species, such as Gambusia, which feed on and help to control the population of mosquito larvae in their aquatic habitats.

questions.text: As per WHO categorization of bioterrorism agents, Anthrax belongs to (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

The WHO categorizes bioterrorism agents into three main categories based on their potential impact on public health and their ease of dissemination.

 

Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) is classified as a Category A agent, which includes the highest priority agents that pose the greatest risk to national security and public health.

 

Category A agents are easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, cause high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Includes agents that are moderately easy to disseminate and result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance.

 

Option C. Category C: Includes NEW emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production and dissemination, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates.

 

Option D. Category D: Not a recognized category by WHO for bioterrorism agents.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Anthrax is the MC used bioterrorism agent
  • Small pox is the most dangerous bioterrorism agent
  • Botulism most lethal toxin wise bioterrorism agent

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Polio

 

  • Mass immunization is one of the best strategies to deal with outbreak of poliomyelitis.
  • Outbreak response immunization (ORI): Following the Acute flaccid paralysis case investigation and stool specimen collection, ORI is organized in community.
  • Children aged 0-59 months are given one dose of OPV regardless of previous immunization (in the village/locality of the AFP case)
  • Travel history of the child with AFP may suggest additional places of stay where ORI should also be conducted
  • Atleast 500 children are vaccinated

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cholera: In case of a cholera outbreak, the most effective response would be chemoprophylaxis for a household or a closed community and. Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is Tetracycline.

 

Option B. Typhoid: control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, prevent carriers from handling food, milk or water from others, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Vaccination is not advised for typhoid outbreaks.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Tetanus is not a communicable disease in the traditional sense as it does not spread from person to person. Instead, it is caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds. Thus, mass vaccination for tetanus isn't typically utilized as an outbreak response but is important in routine immunization schedules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

 

Additional Information

 

Outbreak response for Measles includes

 

  1. Isolation for 7 days after the onset of rash
  2. Immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure (if vaccine is contraindicated, immunoglobulins should be given within 3-4 days of exposure)
  3. Prompt immunization at the beginning of an epidemic is essential to limit the spread.

questions.text: The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical parameter used to evaluate maternal health within countries. In the context of public health statistics, how is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for a country conventionally expressed? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, providing a measure of the safety and quality of maternal care in a country.

questions.text:
Dr. Geeta, a senior epidemiologist in Delhi, receives weekly updates on the prevalence of several diseases in the states/region she oversees. Recently, she noticed distinct patterns in three different diseases over a two-week period: [AIIMS NOV 2017]

 

Disease 1: Number of cases last week = 42, this week = 43

 

Disease 2: Number of cases last week 2 and present week 42

 

Disease 3: Number of cases last week 6 and present week 1

 

How should these diseases be categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Endemic, epidemic, sporadic

 

Disease 1 - The similarity of the cases suggests that it must be endemic.

 

Disease 2 - The surge in case numbers is deeply concerning, suggesting the potential emergence of an epidemic.

 

Disease 3 - The decrease in the number of cases has occurred without a clear explanation, suggesting that it may be sporadic in nature. An epidemic, on the other hand, is characterized by the occurrence of a disease at a rate exceeding the expected frequency.

 

Endemic

 

  • Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
  • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
  • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Pandemic

 

  • An epidemic usually affecting a large proportion of the population, occurring over a large geographical area such as part of a nation, nation, continent or world (Country-to-country spread)

 

Sporadic

 

  • Cases which are ‘scattered about’
    • Cases are widely separated in space and time
    • Show little or no connection with each other
    • There is no recognizable source of infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic diseases show a stable presence, epidemics show a sudden increase in cases, and sporadic diseases occur irregularly.

questions.text: A diagram illustrating the natural history of a disease has points marked A, B, C, and D. Which point indicates the onset of symptoms in the disease's natural history? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Point C

 

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

 

Option B. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During a telemedicine session with patients in a rural health clinic, Dr. Reddy emphasized preventive measures for COVID-19. He highlighted certain practices that are widely recommended. Which of the following, however, is NOT effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1% glutaraldehyde

 

  • A 1% glutaraldehyde solution does not prove effective in preventing the transmission of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face Mask: Wearing face masks significantly helps reduce the transmission of COVID-19 by blocking respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. 70% Alcohol: Alcoholic solutions, particularly those containing at least 60-70% alcohol, are effective in killing viruses on surfaces and are recommended for hand sanitation to reduce viral transmission.

 

Option D. Hand Washing: Regular and thorough hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is one of the most effective ways to remove viruses and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key measures that effectively curb its spread include behaviors such as maintaining a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others, washing hands with soap and water for a duration of 20 seconds, or employing a hand sanitizer containing a minimum of 70% alcohol.
  • Additionally, wearing a face mask in situations necessitating public outings remains crucial.

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the refugees returning from war in a camp? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trench latrine

 

For temporary sanitation facilities in refugee camps, the recommended options are shallow trench latrines, deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines. Among the given choices, the "trench latrine" option is the most appropriate for providing sanitation facilities to refugees returning from war in a camp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pit method - This option is incorrect because the " Pit method " is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps

 

Option B. Dumping method - This option is incorrect because the "dumping method" is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps.

 

Option D. Aqua privy - Aqua privies, which are similar to septic tanks, are useful at the family level but not recommended for temporary refugee camps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When providing temporary sanitation facilities for refugees in camps, trench latrines (either shallow or deep) are the recommended option, as they are suitable for short-term use and can be easily set up in such situations.

questions.text: Two distinct patient cohorts at AIIMS New Delhi are subjected to different treatments to monitor their post-treatment blood pressure levels. The groups do not have overlapping members. Which statistical test would best suit the analysis of the blood pressure differences between the two groups? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unpaired t test

 

  • In the provided situation, two distinct groups are under comparison, and therefore, the appropriate statistical analysis would involve employing a Student's t-test or an unpaired t-test.
  • T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t test: Used when comparing the same group before and after an intervention, not suitable for independent groups.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means among three or more groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data, not for comparing means of continuous data.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? [NEET PG 2022]

Ans. (a) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

 

Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive scheme, pregnant women who deliver in healthcare facilities are provided financial assistance. The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

 

Madhya Pradesh is categorized as a Low Performing State (LPS), the incentives are as follows:

 

  • Mother's Package: ₹1000
  • ASHA's Package: ₹400

questions.text: You are participating in a research discussion about the best approach to study the circadian changes in the fat content of expressed breast milk among mothers of preterm babies. The primary aim is to observe the variations over time and establish a temporal relationship. Which of the following study designs would be most suitable to achieve this objective? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Prospective Cohort

 

  • The study design of choice for the given scenario is a prospective study.
  • In the given situation, the study cohort would comprise of mothers with preterm infants, whereas the control cohort would include mothers with full-term babies.
  • To investigate the diurnal fluctuations in the fat composition of expressed breast milk, samples of breast milk would be collected at designated time points each day.
  • These samples would be monitored over the course of multiple days and subjected to analysis. This research constitutes a prospective study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambispective Cohort: An Ambispective cohort includes both retrospective and prospective cohort study. This case scenario will not fit in retrospective study

 

Option C. Case control: Case-control study is also a retrospective study.

 

Option D. Cross sectional: Cross-sectional study is used to figure out the prevalence of a disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.

The mother is anxious and wants to ensure her child receives all the necessary immunizations. You explain that one of the shots the child will receive is the Pentavalent vaccine, which combines five different immunizations into a single injection. Which of the following immunizations are combined in the Pentavalent vaccine? [INICET MAY 2021]

Ans. (d) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to OPD at PHC for her general health check-up. Parents told the medical officer that currently she isn’t enrolled in any school. Which program is going to benefit the girl? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ICDS

 

Explanation:

 

The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program, established in 1975, focuses on improving the health, nutrition, and education of young children, adolescent girls, and women.

For a 10-year-old girl not enrolled in any school, the ICDS program, which operates through Anganwadi centers, is most suitable. The Anganwadi center provides health check-ups, nutritional supplementation, immunizations, and counseling services appropriate for her age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid day meal program: This program is available only in schools and thus does not benefit a girl not enrolled in any school.

 

Option C. RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram): Focuses on health screening and early intervention for children enrolled in schools and Anganwadi centers but is not the most direct benefit for a non-school-going girl.

 

Option D. NSSK (Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram): Targets the care of newborns and is irrelevant for a 10-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ICDS program provides comprehensive health and nutritional benefits for children up to 6 years and adolescent girls up to 18 years through Anganwadi centers, making it the ideal choice for a 10-year-old girl not enrolled in school.

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

questions.text: A biostatistician is reviewing data from a recent research study. She observes that the confidence interval (CI) for one of the primary outcomes is quite wide. Which of the following factors is least likely to contribute to the widening of the confidence interval? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Increasing sample size

 

A confidence interval (CI) provides a range of values within which we can be reasonably certain that the population parameter lies. The width of the CI can be influenced by several factors:

 

  • Increase in sample size: As the sample size increases, the margin of error decreases, resulting in a narrower confidence interval. Therefore, an increase in sample size is least likely to contribute to the widening of the CI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in sample size: A smaller sample size increases the margin of error, leading to a wider confidence interval. This is because with fewer observations, there is more uncertainty about the estimate.

 

Option C. Increase in variability: Higher variability in the data increases the margin of error, which in turn widens the confidence interval. Variability affects the precision of the estimate.

 

Option D. Increase in confidence level: Increasing the confidence level (e.g., from 95% to 99%) requires a larger range to ensure that the true population parameter is captured with greater certainty, thus widening the confidence interval.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A smaller sample size or a higher variability will result in a wider confidence interval with a larger margin of error
  • As sample size increases, the margin of error decreases
  • As the variability in the population increases, the margin of error increases
  • As you increase the confidence level (e.g., 95% to 99%) while holding the sample size and variability constant, the confidence interval widens
  • Smaller the SD, narrower is Confidence interval

questions.text: Under MTP Act of India, for cases of MTP after 24 weeks POG, there has to be a Medical board to advise. It comprises of all except: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Legal advisor


Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, a Medical Board must be constituted for termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks, specifically in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. This board plays a crucial role in evaluating the circumstances and approving the procedure when necessary. The Medical Board is required to have specific members to provide expert medical advice, including:

 

  1. An Obstetrician-Gynaecologist who provides expertise on maternal and fetal health.
  2. A Radiologist who is crucial for diagnosing fetal anomalies through imaging.
  3. A Paediatrician who offers insights into the potential viability and health of the fetus.
  4. Members nominated by state government in official Gazette

 

These experts collectively evaluate the condition to ensure a medically sound decision. However, the board does not include a legal advisor, as their role is primarily medical, focusing on the health aspects rather than legal counsel.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Medical Board for MTP cases beyond 24 weeks includes an Obstetrician-Gynaecologist, Radiologist, and Paediatrician but does not include a legal advisor.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with 2-3 hypopigmented, slightly raised patches on his forearm with reduced sensation for 4 months. He is diagnosed with paucibacillary leprosy. What is the recommended treatment regimen? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 2 drug therapy for 6 months

 

  • The treatment regimen for paucibacillary leprosy involves a 6-month course of drug therapy with 2 drugs (Dapsone, Rifampicin).
  • Diagnosis of leprosy under NLEP: It is currently based on clinical grounds (revised case definition) - 

 

Paucibacillary (PB) case: A case of leprosy with 1 to 5 skin lesions, without demonstrated presence of bacilli in a skin smear;

 

Multibacillary (MB) case: A case of leprosy with more than five skin lesions; or with nerve involvement (pure neuritis, or any number of skin lesions and neuritis); or with the demonstrated presence of bacilli in a slit-skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

PBL child - Blue color

 

MBL child - Yellow colour

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

questions.text: A 28-year-old public health nurse is attending a seminar on primary prevention strategies. She needs to identify interventions that fall under specific protection, a subset of primary prevention. Which of the following interventions does NOT come under the primary level of prevention for specific protection? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Hand washing

 

  • Specific protection mode of disease prevention: Is a Primary level of disease prevention (applied when risk factors are present in environment but disease has not yet taken place).
  • Risk factors are already present but disease is prevented from occurring by using a specific modality. Ex - Vaccines & Vit A supplementation under NIS, chemoprophylaxis, IFA supplementation, contraception, ITN, etc
  • Handwashing fall within the category of primary prevention as a Health Promotion measure, not specific protection, as it is not a protective measures targeted at any particular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis prophylaxis in exposed contacts/relatives: This is a form of specific protection, aimed at preventing the onset of meningitis in those exposed to the infection.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccination is a classic example of specific protection, preventing the occurrence of specific diseases.

 

Option D. Adding iron to wheat flour: This is a specific protection measure to prevent iron deficiency anemia in the population by fortifying commonly consumed food products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hand washing is a health promotion measure and does not fall under specific protection in primary prevention strategies.
  • Note - Chinese Medicine is the Pioneer in concept of ‘Specific protection by vaccine’

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.

For a 9-month-old baby showing signs of some dehydration due to diarrhea, it is crucial to administer 400-700 ml of ORS over the first four hours, adhering to IMNCI guidelines. This approach ensures effective initial rehydration and sets the stage for ongoing recovery and feeding.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. Walter Reed showed that yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.
  2. Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination
  3. James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, Public health expert who works extensively with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India. In a meeting with local health workers in 2017, he has shared the data and progress made in controlling leprosy. He mentions the crucial statistic of the Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) as of March 31, 2016, to give a snapshot of the magnitude of new leprosy cases detected. This rate helps in understanding the effectiveness of ongoing programs and strategies. What value did Dr. Mehta share as the ANCDR for leprosy for that specific year? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 9.7/1 lakh population

 

During the 2015-2016 period, India recorded an annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) for leprosy at 9.7 per 100,000 people.

 

Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR):

 

  • An important Indicator being used under the National Leprosy Eradication Program 
  • Indicator is calculated at the end of March every year, wherein New Cases detected during the period April (Previous Calendar year) and March (current year) is used
  • ANCDR - 2015-16: 9.71 per 100,000 population
  • ANCDR - 2021-22: 5.52 per 100,000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions.
  • For leprosy in India, maintaining a keen understanding of this rate is essential for achieving the goals of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme.

questions.text: Dr. Rajan is a consultant at a primary health center, frequently encountering cases of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs). He usually prefers syndromic approach for managing these conditions due to limited diagnostic facilities. A 28-year-old male patient walks in, presenting with discharge from his urethra, indicating a possible urethritis. The patient is unaware of the specific causative organism. Given the syndromic management approach, which combination of medications would Dr. Rajan most likely prescribe to effectively treat both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cefixime + Azithromycin

 

  •  According to the syndromic approach for managing STIs/RTIs, the preferred treatment for both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis involves a combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a ‘discrete probability distribution’ that expresses the ‘probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of time’ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poisson’s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution and Option D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides – ‘bell shaped distribution’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text: In an automobile manufacturing company, the HR department notes an increase in absenteeism among the factory workers over the past six months. The company collaborates with a public health expert to investigate the reasons. The expert decides to use the metric of sickness absenteeism as a tool. What is the primary aspect this metric would evaluate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Health of the worker

 

Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used as an indicator of the occupational health of the employees. High sickness absenteeism indicates poor occupational health of the workers.

 

Sickness absenteeism is a ‘useful index in industry to assess the state of health of workers’, and their physical, mental and social well-being. Rate of absenteeism reported in India is 8 – 10 days per worker per year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Health of the family: Sickness absenteeism does not directly assess the health of the worker's family.

 

Option C. Industrial environment: While the industrial environment can affect absenteeism, the metric specifically evaluates worker health.

 

Option D. Community health: Sickness absenteeism focuses on the health of the workers, not the broader community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickness absenteeism primarily evaluates the health of the worker and is a key indicator of occupational health.

 

Methods of reducing sickness absenteeism:

 

  • Good factory management and practices
  • Adequate pre-placement examination
  • Good human relations
  • Application of ergonomics

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text:
Consider the following Statements? [INICET NOV 2023]

 

  • Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
  • Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
  • Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
  • Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

1. Contemplation: A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking. This statement correctly aligns with the contemplation phase where an individual acknowledges the problem and begins to think seriously about solving it soon but hasn’t committed to action yet.

 

3. Maintenance phase/determination phase: A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then. This is an accurate description of the maintenance phase, where the individual has made significant changes and is focused on maintaining these changes long-term. The use of "determination phase" here is non-standard; typically, it is just called "maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Precontemplation: A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health. This statement is incorrect for this phase. The precontemplation phase is characterized by a lack of awareness or denial of the problem, not considering changes. The correct description would be not considering the benefits or need for exercise.

 

4. Action phase: A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family. This statement incorrectly describes the action phase. The action phase involves active modification of behavior. This description instead suggests resignation or justification for inaction, which could fit the precontemplation or contemplation phase but is misaligned with the proactive nature of the action phase.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Behavior change – 6 stages –

 

Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition. [NEET PG  2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a resource-limited setting presents to a local health camp with complaints of chronic eye irritation and a gritty feeling in her eyes for the past few months. On examination, conjunctival scarring and inward turning of the eyelashes are noted. The physician suspects trachoma and recalls the recommended WHO's SAFE strategy for managing trachoma in endemic areas. What does the "S" in the SAFE strategy stand for in this context? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Surgery 

 

The "S" in the SAFE strategy stands for Surgery, specifically for the correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion.

 

The SAFE Strategy for Trachoma:

 

S – Surgery (for correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion)

A – Antibiotic (Azithromycin)

F – Facial cleanliness to prevent disease transmission

E - Environmental change to increase access to water and sanitation.

 

Trachoma (rough eye) 

 

A microbial infection of the eye caused due to the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is a contagious disease, that can be easily spread by direct contact with an affected person, by means of their eyes, eyelids, nasal and throat secretions and exchange of used towels and handkerchiefs. 

 

The risk factors of trachoma are poor sanitation, crowded living conditions and lack of routine hygiene practices due to poverty. Moreover, trachoma commonly occurs in children between the ages of 2-5 years, more frequently in adult women than men and in surroundings where flies are rampant, as these can serve as vectors to transmit the bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "S" in the WHO's SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery.

 

Additional Information

 

Trachoma Treatment

 

  • Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20 mg/kg oral stat
  • Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma:
    • District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
    • District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
    • District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary
  • Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO]
    • Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age
    • Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days

 

India declared ‘Trachoma-Free’ in December 2017.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the effect of Dietary modification on Serum cholesterol. A group of 100 people were chosen. Their mean cholesterol levels were measured before and after dietary modification. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paired student’s t-test

 

The paired student’s t-test is used when comparing the means of two related groups, specifically when data is collected from the same individuals before and after an intervention. In this question, the study measures serum cholesterol levels before and after dietary modification in the same group of people, making the data paired. This test is ideal for assessing whether the mean difference between the paired observations (pre- and post-intervention) is statistically significant.

 

Since the data is quantitative and normally distributed, a parametric test such as the paired t-test is appropriate. The paired t-test accounts for the fact that each participant has two related measurements (before and after), which reduces variability compared to independent measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Odds Ratio:  This option is incorrect because the odds ratio is used to measure the association between two categorical variables, not for comparing means of quantitative data.

 

Option B. Chi-square test:  This test is used to compare categorical data and is not suitable for comparing means of quantitative measurements.

 

Option D. McNemar test:  This test is used to analyze paired categorical data, specifically for before-and-after studies with binary outcomes, not for comparing continuous variables like cholesterol levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The paired student’s t-test is the appropriate statistical test for comparing means of paired quantitative data collected from the same group before and after an intervention.

questions.text: A 38-year-old public health officer is deployed to a rural area where there is increasing concern regarding the consumption of Khesari dal by the local community for the past year. In a meeting with the local healthcare team, various preventive measures are discussed to counteract the potential outbreak of lathyrism associated with Khesari dal. Which of the following interventions is NOT recommended in this context? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. DEC

 

Lathyrism is a neurological disease caused by consuming the pulse Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus), which contains the toxin beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA). Preventive measures to counteract lathyrism focus on removing the toxin, banning the crop, using Vitamin C as a prophylactic measure, and other strategies. Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is not related to the prevention of lathyrism and is primarily used in the treatment of filariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxin Removal: Steeping and parboiling methods are recommended to remove the toxin from Khesari dal.

 

Option B. Crop Ban: Banning the cultivation of Khesari dal is a recommended intervention to prevent lathyrism.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C is used as a prophylactic measure to prevent lathyrism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lathyrism

 

  • Lathyrism is of two types:
    • Neurolathyrism: in human beings
    • Osteolathyrism (odoratism): In animals 
  • Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘khesari dal (lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal   consumed over a period of 2-6 months result in neurolathyrism
  • Lathyrism affects 15-45 years of age
  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seed is ‘beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C prophylaxis
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: steeping method and parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes
