questions.text: During a journal club discussion on a randomized controlled trial comparing two surgical techniques for direct inguinal hernia, the reported p-value is 0.04. What is the most accurate interpretation of this p-value? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

 

  • With a calculated p-value of 0.04, we can deduce that there is a 4% chance of arriving at a false positive conclusion, suggesting that operation A is superior to operation B.
  • In this context, the p-value of 0.04 attains statistical significance by conventional standards.
  • Consequently, we have grounds to reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis, indicating that operation A outperforms operation B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 suggests that there is a statistically significant difference, at the 5% significance level, between the surgical techniques being compared, assuming the risk of a false positive conclusion is acceptable at 4%.

questions.text: A 28-year-old epidemiologist is tasked with visually representing the current outbreak of diarrhea in a district. She wants to showcase the trends and fluctuations of the cases over a period of time to the local health authorities. Which type of graphical representation would be the most appropriate for her to use in order to display these temporal trends effectively? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Line chart

 

Line chart or graph is a frequency polygon presenting variations by time.

 

 

It shows the trend of an event over a period of time. Like diarrhea cases in an epidemic area over a period of given time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bar Diagram: it is for visual comparison of magnitude of different frequencies in a data.

 

 

Option C. Pie Diagram: it is for presentation of discrete data of qualitative characteristics.

 

 

Option D. Spot Map: is prepared to show geographical distribution of frequencies of characteristic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For displaying temporal trends and fluctuations of disease cases over time, a line chart is the most effective and appropriate graphical representation.

questions.text: According to antenatal care, the recommended ideal number of ANC visits should be: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12-14

 

The recommended ideal number of antenatal care (ANC) visits is typically 12 to 14. The schedule for these visits is generally as follows:

 

  • First 7 months (up to 28 weeks): One visit per month (7 visits).
  • 8th month (29-32 weeks): Two visits in the month (2 visits).
  • 9th month (33 weeks onwards): One visit per week (4-5 visits).

 

This schedule results in a total of 13 to 14 visits during the entire pregnancy. This number ensures that both the mother and the fetus are adequately monitored throughout the pregnancy, allowing for timely identification and management of any complications.

 

Note –

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least minimum 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts." This is to ensure a basic level of care during pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of antenatal care visits recommended for a normal pregnancy is 12-14 to ensure optimal monitoring and care.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

  • Cohort study is the most effective study design for showcasing the connection between a cause and an effect. A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’. It is known by several synonyms:
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-control study: Case Control Study cannot provide with incidences, so Relative Risk cannot be calculated; In a Case Control Study, we calculate ‘an estimate of Relative Risk’, known as ‘Odds Ratio’ (CROSS PRODUCT RATIO).

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population. It cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’.

 

Option D. Clinical trials: Clinical trials evaluates new studies, drugs and treatment effects on human population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text: Casal's necklace is seen with which vitamin deficiency?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra. Niacin can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, with 60 mg of tryptophan converting to 1 mg of niacin daily. Tryptophan deficiency is common in maize-based diets, but the actual reason for pellagra in maize eaters is not tryptophan deficiency itself, but rather an excess of leucine, which prevents the conversion of tryptophan to niacin. Leucine is therefore known as the pellagrogenic amino acid of India.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death. The dermatitis associated with pellagra often occurs around the neck or on the extremities of the body, particularly on areas of skin that are directly exposed to sunlight. When this dermatitis occurs around the neck, it may lead to the formation of Casal's necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency is not associated with Casal's necklace. Instead, it can lead to beriberi in polished rice eaters and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency is not related to Casal's necklace. It can cause scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is not linked to Casal's necklace. It can cause peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, and pernicious anemia, especially in strict vegetarians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen around the neck in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra.
